newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela/Brasil nearing oil joint-venture - PDVSA.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela/Brasil nearing oil joint-venture - PDVSA.

text.p: Venezuela and Brasil are nearing a decision on how the neighbouring state oil companies can link up to take advantage of each other's oil reserves and markets, Venezuelan officials said on Wednesday.

The two countries are naturally matched -- Venezuela has the world's sixth largest proven oil reserves and Brazilian huge market for oil is expected to grow at 5 percent per year for the next ten years -- but the two have so far failed to reach a concrete agreement.
Officials from state-owned Petroleos de Venezuela had hoped to form a joint company last month.
A delegation from Brasil's Petrobras is expected to arrive in Caracas next week to continue talks about a range of joint- venture options, said Jose Toro Hardy, a PDVSA director.

Toro Hardy said the options included oil exploration and production in Venezuela, buying a Caribbean refinery or upgrading a Venezuelan one, building a refined product import terminal in north-east Brazil, and Venezuela selling natural gas liquids (NGL) to Brazil. They could also include Brazil taking a stake in a multi-billion dollar Orinoco extra-heavy crude venture.
Brazil's suggestion that the two build a grass-roots refinery in north-east Brazil has been rejected by PDVSA on the grounds that it would be too expensive, he added.
Venezuela currently supplies 120,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil to Brazil, and Petrobras has said it wants to increase this by 10,000 bpd.
